awd_titl_txt: Determining Mechanisms and Rates of Geologic Respiration at Watershed Scales
awd_abstract_narration:
A vast pool of diffuse organic carbon is stored in rocks, constituting 30,000 times the amount of carbon stored in all organisms. During the breakdown of rocks and formation of soil, organic carbon stored in rocks is released as carbon dioxide into the atmosphere.  Understanding the controls on this release of carbon is important for understanding the history of Earth's climate, and is also essential for evaluating how human impacts may be affecting this large reservoir of carbon. This proposed research project specifically investigates how mountain building and erosion control the release of organic carbon from rocks.  The project will provide research experience and training for graduate and undergraduate students, including highly specialized techniques in organic and trace metal geochemistry. A new partnership will be developed between the US and international scientific communities studying the Earth's "critical zone" where rock, soil, water, air, and living organisms interact. The PIs will partner with two local programs to engage underrepresented groups at the middle and high school level through curriculum development for summer camp programs. These educational and outreach efforts will support and deepen existing relationships to promote increased participation of underrepresented groups in STEM fields.  Ultimately this research will contribute to more accurate modeling of the global carbon and oxygen cycles, improving understanding of how the Earth has maintained habitability over geologic timescales and better constrain predictions of future change in atmospheric carbon dioxide.

Mineralization of organic carbon in rocks, a process known as geologic respiration, is a major CO2 source to the atmosphere and thus a major control on Earth's climate over geologic timescales. The goal of this research project is to resolve a current paradox surrounding the relationship between erosion and geologic respiration. The relationship between geologic respiration and physical erosion rates will be characterized by studying watersheds with contrasting tectonic uplift, erosion, and sediment yields. Dissolved rhenium (Re) will be tested as a tracer of geologic respiration. Current understanding is that rhenium is released during bedrock weathering and conservatively delivered to surface water at a rate comparable to that of CO2 release. The utility of dissolved riverine Re as a quantitative tracer will be evaluated, and the importance of riverine particulate Re for accurate estimation of geologic respiration rates will also be verified. The proposed research includes a multi-scale analysis of geologic respiration from the weathering profile scale up through the watershed scale in well-constrained small mountainous river basins along the West Coast of the US.  Laboratory analyses will include both soil and rock samples from weathering profiles and dissolved and particulate fractions of river samples collected across a wide range of flow conditions.  Measurements of Re, 14C, biomarker analyses of organic carbon, and other geochemical tracers will be combined and analyzed in order to characterize the sources, flowpaths, and processes that deliver Re and rock-derived organic carbon from upland landscapes to rivers.  While quantifying the rates and evaluating the key controls on geologic respiration in the target river basins, this research will also develop the understanding to make such determinations worldwide.

por.por_cntn:
Sedimentary rocks in the earth's crust contain a large amount of organic carbon, approximately 350-fold greater than all other surface carbon reservoirs (e.g., oceans, atmosphere, biota, soils, surface marine sediments) combined.  Oxidation of this rock-associated organic carbon during the weathering of sedimentary rocks represents a source of carbon dioxide to the atmosphere. Recent research has suggested that the carbon dioxide added to the atmosphere via oxidation of sedimentary rock organic carbon may exceed the amount removed via silicate rock weathering.  This represents a fundamental change in our understanding of the Earth’s carbon cycle over geologic timescales, but the rates and mechanisms of sedimentary organic carbon oxidation are not well known. In particular, the importance of tectonic controls, climatic controls, and the role of human activities in controlling rates of rock organic carbon oxidation is not known.  This NSF research project aimed to determine the rates and controls of rock organic carbon oxidation at watershed scales by conducting an intensive study of the distribution and fluxes of rock-derived organic carbon as well as associated elements (including, rhenium (Re)) in soil-bedrock weathering profiles and different order streams. By elucidating the mechanisms driving this major source of atmospheric carbon dioxide, this work aims to fill a key knowledge gap in understanding the global carbon cycle feedbacks that keep Earth habitable over long timescales.

This research project conducted extensive fieldwork and sampling of river waters throughout the Eel River and Umpqua River watersheds in California and Oregon. Along with river water samples collected during a wide range of discharge conditions, soil, weathered rock, rock, river bed materials, and river suspended sediment were sampled and analyzed for their major element, trace element, and isotope geochemistry.  Additional analyses included ramped temperature pyrolysis oxidation coupled to stable carbon (δ13C) and radiocarbon (14C) analyses of sequentially evolved carbon dioxide.

Several outcomes resulted from this research project.  One is that this study presents an in-depth analysis of the use of dissolved riverine Re as a tracer of rock organic carbon oxidation rates. On the basis of the concentration-discharge relationship between dissolved Re and sulfate, as well as disparities in the depth of the weathering front for Re and sulfur, the data indicate that dissolved Re does not trace sulfide oxidation.  This supports that hypothesis that Re is instead derived from oxidation of rock organic carbon.  The data also show that Re is positively correlated with both suspended sediment fluxes and with long term erosion rates based on cosmogenic beryllium, which supports the hypothesis that erosion is the major control on sedimentary rock carbon oxidation rates.  A second major outcome from this work is the characterization of the total dissolved and sediment flux for these rivers, as well as the total dissolved and particulate organic carbon fluxes for these rivers. The analyses showed the highly seasonal nature of material transport in these systems, the inordinate impact of floods on the transport of particulate materials and the critical role of river discharge in determining the magnitude and timing of material fluxes. Examination of flux and compositional data from the most downstream gauges in the Eel and Umpqua rivers in comparison to physical conditions (winds and waves) offshore in the Pacific Ocean illustrated the role that the timing of river delivery plays in the distribution and ultimate fate of the carbon, nutrient, and sediments delivered across the land to sea interface.  While this research project focused on two specific small mountainous river systems in the Pacific Northwest (Eel and Umpqua rivers), they are representative of the moderately eroding sedimentary rock systems that are likely to play a predominant role in the worldwide oxidation of rock-derived organic carbon.
